His GCS is 8/15, oxygen saturation is 85%, BP is 100/ 60 mmHg, and heart rate is 60 beats per minute. On auscultation his right side breath sounds were absent. What is the next step in management?

questions.text: Tigroid white matter on MR imaging is seen in which of the following conditions?
A 40-year-old man presents with wrist pain after a fall on an outstretched hand. The X-ray is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Volar Barton’s fracture

 

A Volar Barton's fracture is an intra-articular fracture of the distal radius involving the volar (palmar) rim and is associated with dislocation or subluxation of the radiocarpal joint towards the volar side. The X-ray in question shows a fracture of the distal radius with the carpal bones displaced volarly along with a fragment of the volar rim, which fits this classic description. The hallmark is an intra-articular fracture with volar subluxation of the carpus.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Colles' fracture: A Colles' fracture is an extra-articular distal radius fracture with dorsal displacement and angulation, not volar.

 

Option B. Smith’s fracture: A Smith’s fracture is an extra-articular fracture of the distal radius with volar (palmar) displacement but does not involve the articular surface or subluxation of the carpus.

 

Option D. Scaphoid fracture: A scaphoid fracture specifically involves one of the carpal bones, not the distal radius, and would not show the radiocarpal displacement described

questions.text: Identify the correct pair:

A 45-year-old male presented with something coming out per anus (SCOPA) and splash in the pan type of blood in stools. On examination, the mass remains outside and has crossed the anal verge but can be manually reduced. Which is the grade of the disease?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 3

 

  • Hemorrhoids are symptomatic enlargements of the internal haemorrhoidal venous plexus (Greek: haima = blood, rhoos = flowing; synonym: piles, Latin: pila = a ball). Internal hemorrhoids characteristically lie in the 3, 7, and 11 o’clock positions (with the patient in the lithotomy position)
  • The internal haemorrhoidal plexus constitutes the submucosal component of the anal cushions that are important in sealing the anal canal. 
  • Man’s upright posture, the absence of valves in the portal venous system and raised abdominal pressure due to pregnancy or particularly through straining during defecation contribute to venous plexus engorgement and development of varicosities. Shearing forces lead to mucosal trauma (bleeding) and caudal displacement of the anal cushions (prolapse).

 

Four degrees of hemorrhoids:

 

  • First degree - Bleed only, no prolapse
  • Second degree - Prolapse but reduce spontaneously
  • Third degree - Prolapse but have to be manually reduced
  • Fourth degree - Permanently prolapsed

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • Grade III internal hemorrhoids are characterized by prolapse during straining or defecation that can be manually reduced, distinguishing them from Grade IV, which are irreducible.

questions.text: The following condition develops due to which vessel?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Medial circumflex femoral artery

 

Avascular necrosis (AVN) of the femoral head typically develops after disruption of its main blood supply, which is almost entirely provided by the medial circumflex femoral artery in adults. This vessel gives rise to the posterior retinacular arteries that run along the femoral neck and supply the head; injury, especially after femoral neck fractures or hip dislocation, can easily compromise flow and cause AVN. The other arteries (especially the artery of the ligamentum teres from the obturator artery) provide only a minor supply in adults, so interruption of the medial circumflex femoral artery is the critical event leading to AVN in these settings.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Lateral circumflex femoral artery: Primarily supplies the lateral thigh muscles and the anterior capsule of the hip, with only minor contribution to the femoral head. Injury to this vessel does not commonly result in AVN.

 

Option C. Obturator artery: Contributes minimally in adults via the artery of the ligamentum teres; its role in femoral head perfusion is insignificant after early childhood.

 

Option D. Profunda femoris artery: Mainly a parent vessel for the circumflex arteries, it does not directly supply the femoral head and is not relevant for AVN risk unless a branch is involved.

questions.text:
In which of the following vessels will the blood flow get affected if one puts a temporary clamp near the origin of the common hepatic artery?

 

  1. ﻿﻿﻿Right gastric
  2. ﻿﻿﻿Right gastroepiploic
  3. ﻿﻿﻿Replaced left hepatic
  4. ﻿﻿﻿Left gastroepiploic
  5. ﻿﻿﻿Left hepatic
  6. Superior pancreaticoduodenal
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1, 2, 5, 6

 

To answer this question, we need to understand the branches of the common hepatic artery (CHA) and which downstream vessels would have their blood flow affected if a clamp is placed near its origin.

 

The common hepatic artery (CHA) is a branch of the celiac trunk and gives rise to the following major branches:

 

1. Proper hepatic artery, which then gives:

  • Right hepatic artery

→ Cystic artery

  • Left hepatic artery
  • Occasionally, right gastric artery arises here

2. Gastroduodenal artery, which gives:

  • Right gastroepiploic artery
  • Superior pancreaticoduodenal artery

 

Correct options:

 

1. Right gastric artery – Usually arises from the proper hepatic artery, a branch of CHA → Affected

 

2. Right gastroepiploic artery – Branch of gastroduodenal artery, which arises from CHA → Affected

 

5. Left hepatic artery – Usually a branch of proper hepatic artery → Affected 

 

6.Superior pancreaticoduodenal artery – Branch of gastroduodenal artery, which comes from CHA → Affected

 

Incorrect options:

 

3. Replaced left hepatic artery – If replaced, this means it arises not from CHA → Not affected

 

4. Left gastroepiploic artery – Arises from splenic artery, not from CHA → Not affected

questions.text: A 59-year-old man comes to the OPD due to headaches. He describes the headaches as diffuse and says that they get worse when he leans forward. He has not had any fever, vomiting, or chest pain but has a chronic cough. He has an extensive smoking history and quit smoking 4 years ago. Blood pressure is 100/60 mm Hg and pulse is 100/min. CECT is shown below. Which of the following would most likely relieve this patient’s symptoms?

A 72-year-old man presents with severe abdominal distension, pain, and absolute constipation for the past two days. Physical examination reveals a distended, tympanic abdomen. What is the most likely diagnosis?

choices.text: Systolic anterior motion of mitral valve

questions.text: A 46-year-old man complains of dyspnoea and chest discomfort. He believes that the symptoms are due to a respiratory infection he had 4 weeks ago, but he did not see a doctor at that time. ECHO is shown below. Which of the following additional findings may be seen?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) High-pitched, early diastolic sound

 

This describes a pericardial knock, which is characteristic of constrictive pericarditis—a known complication following viral infection affecting the heart. The echo shown likely demonstrates features of constrictive pericarditis, such as septal bounce and abnormal ventricular filling.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Systolic anterior motion of mitral valve: This is seen in hypertrophic cardiomyopathy, not typically following viral myocarditis or pericarditis; echo would show thickened septum and MV displacement, not constriction.

 

 

Option C. Delta wave on ECG: Indicates Wolff-Parkinson-White syndrome due to an accessory pathway; aka canal of Kent. Image shows Delta wave and prolonged PR.

 

 

Option D. Inferonasal ectopia lentis: This is an ocular sign most commonly seen in homocystinuria, not in cardiac or pericardial conditions resulting from viral infection.

questions.text: A 32-year-old man is brought to the emergency department due to progressive confusion and lethargy over the past several hours. The patient has no significant medical history but he has been depressed since a recent breakup with his girlfriend. He works at an automotive repair shop, and one of his coworkers reported seeing the patient consume antifreeze prior to symptom onset. Blood pressure is 110/66 mmHg, pulse is 110/min, and respirations are 24/min. Bilateral costovertebral angles are tender to percussion. Bladder catheterization yields a small amount of bloody urine. Which of the following is most likely to be seen on this patient's arterial blood gas analysis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) pH 7.3, pO2 95, pCO2 24, HCO3 19

 

  • Ethylene glycol poisoning → high anion gap metabolic acidosis with partial respiratory compensation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. pH 7.1, pO2 47, pCO2 45, HCO3 19:Low pO2 → Not seen.

 

Option C. pH 7.6, pO2 95, pCO2 18, HCO3 40:Metabolic alkalosis → Not relevant.

 

Option D. pH 7.4, pO2 95, pCO2 24, HCO3 29: Normal ABG → Wrong.

questions.text: Identify the likely pathology from the thyroid scan pattern shown in the figure:

A 32-year-old man presents with a history of infertility. Semen analysis reveals azoospermia. A testicular biopsy is performed, showing histological findings which is given below. Based on these findings, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Sertoli cell-only syndrome

 

  • The histological image shows seminiferous tubules that contain Sertoli cells but lack germ cells, which is characteristic of Sertoli cell-only syndrome (also known as Del Castillo syndrome).
  • Sertoli cell-only syndrome, is a condition characterized by the absence of germ cells in the seminiferous tubules.
  • Testicular biopsy in these patients shows seminiferous tubules lined by Sertoli cells without evidence of spermatogenesis.
  • Leydig cells are present and functional, maintaining normal testosterone levels.
  • This condition leads to azoospermia and infertility, as seen in this patient. The absence of germ cells is the defining histological feature.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Klinefelter syndrome: Klinefelter syndrome (47,XXY) typically presents with small, firm testes due to fibrosis of the seminiferous tubules and hyalinization. Testicular biopsy reveals sclerosis and atrophy of seminiferous tubules with absent or reduced spermatogenesis. While it also causes infertility, the histology differs from Sertoli cell-only syndrome.

 

Option C. Testicular torsion: Testicular torsion results in ischemia and necrosis of testicular tissue. Histology would show coagulative necrosis, hemorrhage, and loss of cellular structure. This is an acute condition and is not consistent with the biopsy findings in this case.

 

Option D. Mumps orchitis: Mumps orchitis, a complication of mumps infection, results in inflammation and atrophy of testicular tissue. Histology shows interstitial inflammation and fibrosis with tubular atrophy. It is not characterized by a complete absence of germ cells with preserved Sertoli cells as seen in Sertoli cell-only syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Sertoli cell-only syndrome is characterized by the absence of germ cells in the seminiferous tubules, leading to azoospermia and infertility. 
  • Testicular biopsy reveals seminiferous tubules lined by Sertoli cells without evidence of spermatogenesis.

questions.text: Identify the X ray shown below.

A 19-year-old male patient comes to the clinic for follow-up 3 weeks after a traumatic fracture in his right thigh. On examination, he was found to have a hard palpable mass near the fracture site. X-ray of the area shows the findings below. A histological section shows central fibrous tissue and mature bone at the periphery. Which of the following is true about this patient's diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Myositis ossificans

 

The clinical history, X-ray findings, and histology all support this diagnosis.

 

X-ray and Histology Features

 

  • Myositis ossificans typically shows peripheral bone or calcification with a relatively lucent (less dense) center on radiographs.
  • Histologically, it is characterized by mature bone at the periphery and central immature fibrous tissue (“zone phenomenon”), which distinguishes it from parosteal osteosarcoma.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Parosteal osteosarcoma: Parosteal osteosarcoma shows central, dense mineralization often fused with bone, which is not seen in this case.

 

 

Option C. Osteochondroma: Osteochondroma is a bone-cartilage growth usually attached to bone and has a different appearance and histology.

 

 

Option D. AV fistula: AV fistula is a vascular abnormality with no ossification or zonal histology

questions.text: The imaging shows a detailed cross-sectional view of the esophageal wall and surrounding structures. All of the following are uses of this imaging modality except:
questions.solution: Ans. D) Evaluation of gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD)

questions.text: The fracture  seen in the x-ray given below is:

A 30-year-old woman presents to the clinic with chronic wrist pain and reduced range of motion in her forearm. An X-ray of her forearm is obtained, as shown below. What is the most likely deformity identified in this X-ray?

A 40-year-old man presents with a complaint of dragging his foot while walking. On examination, following appearance is noted. This clinical presentation is most likely due to a lesion affecting which nerve?
What is the type of fracture shown in the X-ray of left shoulder?
What is the following instrument:
Identify what is depicted in the abdominal X-Ray.
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Retrograde pyelogram

 

The abdominal X-ray reveals contrast outlining the renal pelvis and ureters ascending from the bladder, a classic image for a retrograde pyelogram. This procedure involves injecting contrast directly into the ureters via a cystoscope from the bladder upwards, useful for evaluating ureteric anatomy and pathology.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. IVU (Intravenous Urogram): Contrast would be visualized after intravenous injection and excretion by the kidneys, typically showing calyces and renal pelvis first, then progressing down the ureters.

 

Option C. Ureteric stent: Would show a radiopaque stent along the ureter, not contrast outlining the urothelium.

 

Option D. MCU with vesico-ureteric reflux: A micturating cystourethrogram shows bladder filling and possible reflux of contrast up the ureters during voiding, but the image does not match that pattern.

questions.text: A 20-year-old woman is evaluated for primary infertility. Hysterosalpingography was done and reveals the finding shown below. What is the anomaly seen in the image?

choices.text: No loss of nerve sheath continuity in Neurapraxia and axonotmesis
Wallerian degeneration is not seen in neurapraxia
Surgical intervention is always needed in neurotmesis
Nerve regrowth happens at 3mm per day

questions.text: Identify the incorrect statement about Seddon classification of nerve injuries:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Nerve regrowth happens at 3mm per day

 

Actual regrowth rate is about 1–3 mm per day (average 1 mm/day).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. No loss of nerve sheath continuity in neurapraxia and axonotmesis:  Correct.

 

  • In neurapraxia → conduction block, myelin damage only.
  • In axonotmesis → axon damage with intact endoneurial sheath.

 

Option B. Wallerian degeneration is not seen in neurapraxia: Correct. Only conduction block occurs, so no distal Wallerian degeneration.

 

Option C. Surgical intervention is always needed in neurotmesis: Correct. In neurotmesis, both axon and supporting sheath are completely disrupted, requiring repair.

questions.text: What is the likely diagnosis based on the skull appearance?
A 6-year-old child presenting with recurrent respiratory infections. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) CPAM

 

Explanation:

 

The images provided, including ultrasound, CT scan, and X-ray findings, are consistent with Congenital Pulmonary Airway Malformation (CPAM).

 

Key features of CPAM:

 

  1. Ultrasound: Shows multiple cystic spaces within the lung parenchyma.
  2. CT scan: Confirms the presence of air-filled cystic lesions in the lung fields.
  3. X-ray: May show cystic areas or hyperinflation, depending on the size and type of lesions.

 

CPAM is a congenital condition characterized by abnormal development of the lung tissue, leading to the formation of cystic or adenomatoid lesions. It often presents in childhood with recurrent respiratory infections due to impaired drainage and ventilation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pyopneumothorax: This would present with an air-fluid level and features of infection (fever, acute symptoms), which are not the primary findings here.

 

Option C. CDH (Congenital Diaphragmatic Hernia): CDH presents with abdominal contents herniating into the thoracic cavity, causing mediastinal shift and respiratory distress, which is not seen in this case.

 

Option D. Lung abscess: Lung abscess typically presents as a thick-walled cavity with air-fluid levels, which is not the pattern seen here.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Congenital Pulmonary Airway Malformation (CPAM) presents with recurrent respiratory infections due to abnormal lung development and cystic changes. Imaging studies, including ultrasound and CT, confirm the diagnosis by identifying multiple cystic lesions within the lung.

questions.text: A 46-year-old male presented to the clinic with a persistent cough, fatigue, weight loss. X-ray of the patient is as given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?

choices.text: Absent breath sounds on the left side

questions.text: A child was intubated, and post-intubation X-ray is shown below. What would be the presenting symptom?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Absent breath sounds on the left side

 

The post-intubation chest X-ray demonstrates the endotracheal tube tip positioned deep in the right main bronchus, causing right lung ventilation and complete collapse of the left lung. This results in absent breath sounds on the left side due to under-ventilation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Right sided tracheal deviation: Would occur with volume loss, not the situation here.

 

Option B. Gastric distension: Suggests esophageal intubation rather than selective bronchial intubation.

 

Option C. Drooling on feeding: Associated with esophageal atresia or tracheoesophageal fistula, unrelated to this X-ray finding.

choices.text: An abscess in the psoas muscle

questions.text: A 75-year-old male patient came to ER with the complaint of severe abdominal pain. CTA was performed which is given below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. A ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm

 

Option B:

 

The CTA shows a soft tissue density with contrast visible outside of the left side of the abdominal aorta. This is a result of extra luminal contrast being expelled from a ruptured aortic aneurysm.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. A ruptured gastric ulcer: A ruptured gastric ulcer typically presents with sudden onset of severe upper abdominal pain that may radiate to the back. On imaging, especially CT, we might see evidence of perforation with free air under the diaphragm (pneumoperitoneum). This finding is not consistent with the provided CTA image.

 

Option C. Acute appendicitis: Patients with acute appendicitis typically present with abdominal pain that begins around the navel and later localizes to the lower right abdomen, accompanied by fever and leukocytosis. A CTA would show an enlarged, inflamed appendix, potentially with an appendicolith (a calcified deposit), but no contrast extravasation outside the aorta as seen in the provided image.

 

Option D. An abscess in the psoas muscle: A psoas abscess would typically present with flank pain, fever, and a palpable mass, or difficulty with movements that involve the psoas muscle. On CTA, an abscess may appear as a well-defined fluid collection with possible enhancement after contrast administration. Again, this does not match the findings in the CTA image provided.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The correct diagnosis is B - A ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm. The provided CTA shows a soft tissue density with contrast visible outside of the left side of the abdominal aorta, indicative of extraluminal contrast from a ruptured aortic aneurysm. This is an urgent surgical emergency requiring immediate attention.

 

 

 

Ref: Grainger & Allison’s Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, Second Edition, Page No 200.

questions.text: Identify the image?

A 57-year-old hospitalized man is evaluated for acute onset of intense periumbilical abdominal pain associated with nausea and vomiting. He has had 2 bowel movements since the pain started. He was admitted 4 days ago for fever, chills, and shortness of breath and was diagnosed with acute bacterial endocarditis. On examination, the patient appears in significant distress and is restless. Temperature is 37.5 C (99.5 F), blood pressure is 150/90 mm Hg, pulse is 110/min and regular, and respirations are 18/min. On abdominal palpation mild diffuse tenderness is present. There is no rigidity or rebound. Bowel sounds are decreased. Xray is shown below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
What is the likely diagnosis based on the MRCP image?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Choledochal cyst

 

The MRCP image you shared shows a large, smooth, cystic dilatation of the common bile duct with communication to the biliary tree.

 

  • Characterized by congenital cystic dilatation of the extrahepatic (± intrahepatic) bile ducts.
  • MRCP: smooth, saccular or fusiform cystic dilatation of CBD → exactly as seen here.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Biliary ascariasis: Would show a linear filling defect (worm) inside the bile duct, not a cystic dilatation.

 

 

Option C. Caroli disease: Involves intrahepatic bile duct dilatation with “central dot sign.” This image shows extrahepatic dilatation, not typical of Caroli.

 

 

Option D. Choledocholithiasis: Would show a filling defect (stone) inside CBD, not a large smooth cystic dilatation.

questions.text:
Match the following staging/grading systems with their respective cancers: 

 

Staging Systems:

  1. Gleason grading
  2. Duke staging
  3. Robson staging
  4. Bloom-Richardson grading

 

Cancers:

  1. Renal cell carcinoma (RCC)
  2. Prostate cancer
  3. Colorectal carcinoma
  4. Breast cancer
questions.solution:
Ans. D) A-2, B-3, C-1, D-4

 

A. Gleason staging – 2. Prostate cancer: This system is used to grade prostate cancer based on histological patterns.

 

B. Duke staging – 3. Colorectal carcinoma: Duke staging is a classic system used to classify colorectal cancer based on the depth of invasion and lymph node involvement.

 

C. Robson staging – 1. Renal cell carcinoma (RCC): Robson's system is a staging classification for RCC based on tumor extent and spread.

 

D. Bloom-Richardson grading – 4. Breast cancer: This system is used to grade breast carcinoma based on histological characteristics such as mitotic count, nuclear grade, and tubule formation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Different cancers have unique staging and grading systems tailored to their anatomical and pathological characteristics. Familiarity with these systems is essential for diagnosis, treatment planning, and prognosis.

questions.text: A diabetic patient presented with acute onset fever and dysuria. Urine examination revealed plenty of leukocytes with glycosuria. A CT scan of the abdomen was done. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Emphysematous pyelonephritis

 

Option B:

 

Given CT scan shows an enlarged kidney with areas of necrosis and mottled areas of gas collection. This is suggestive of emphysematous pyelonephritis.

 

Emphysematous Pyelonephritis (Correct Diagnosis):

 

  • It is an acute, severe infection of the renal parenchyma and surrounding tissues that results in the presence of gas within the renal parenchyma, collecting system, or perinephric tissue.
  • It is more common in diabetic patients and those with urinary obstruction.
  • The CT scan shows mottled gas collections within the renal tissue, characteristic of emphysematous pyelonephritis.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Acute Pyelonephritis:

 

  • This is a bacterial infection causing inflammation of the kidney and renal pelvis.
  • The CT scan might show areas of striated nephrogram or wedge-shaped areas of poor enhancement, but without the presence of gas within the renal parenchyma, which is seen in this case.

 

Option C. Perinephric Abscess:

 

  • It involves the accumulation of pus around the outside of the kidney but within the Gerota fascia.
  • CT findings typically include a fluid collection with an enhancing rim, but not the extensive gas formation within the kidney itself.

 

Option D. Renal Abscess:

 

  • This refers to a localized collection of pus within the renal parenchyma.
  • A CT scan may show a round or oval fluid collection with an enhancing rim within the renal parenchyma, but, again, not typically associated with the extensive gas pattern observed in emphysematous pyelonephritis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

CT scan showing an enlarged kidney with areas of necrosis and mottled areas of gas collection is suggestive of emphysematous pyelonephritis.

questions.text: In patients with renal failure, which imaging technique is appropriate for visualizing vessels without causing further renal impairment?
During the secondary survey of a trauma patient, an AMPLE history is taken to gather critical information. Which of the following is not a part of the AMPLE history?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Lucid interval

 

  • AMPLE history is a rapid mnemonic used during trauma secondary survey:
    • A → Allergies
    • M → Medications currently taken
    • P → Past medical history / Pregnancy
    • L → Last meal
    • E → Events/environment related to the injury
  • Lucid interval is a clinical feature of epidural hematoma, not part of AMPLE history.

A 6-year-old girl is evaluated for early-onset puberty and multiple bone lesions. On examination, she has café-au-lait spots as shown below. Hormonal tests confirm hyperfunction of multiple endocrine glands. What is the underlying genetic mutation in this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) GNAS gene mutation

 

  • The child has café-au-lait spots with irregular borders ("coast of Maine" appearance).
  • Associated with precocious puberty, fibrous dysplasia of bone, and endocrine hyperfunction (eg, hyperthyroidism, Cushing’s, acromegaly).
  • The underlying defect is a somatic activating mutation of the GNAS gene, leading to constitutive activation of G-protein signaling and excess hormone production.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. NF1 gene: Neurofibromatosis type 1; café-au-lait spots but with smooth ("coast of California") borders, neurofibromas, optic gliomas.

 

Option B. GNAQ gene mutation: Sturge–Weber syndrome; port-wine stain, leptomeningeal angiomas, seizures.

 

Option D. FGFR3: Achondroplasia; causes abnormal cartilage growth → short stature, macrocephaly.

A 32-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 3-week history of recurrent thumb pain that worsens with exposure to cold temperatures. Examination shows a 6-mm, blue-red papule under the left thumbnail. The overlying area is extremely tender to palpation. The thumbnail is slightly pitted and cracked. This lesion most likely developed from which of the following types of cells?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Modified smooth muscle cells

 

  • The patient presents with a glomus tumor, a benign tumor of the glomus body, commonly found under the nail (subungual).
  • Classic features: extreme tenderness, paroxysmal pain, cold sensitivity, blue-red subungual papule.
  • Glomus bodies are modified smooth muscle cells involved in thermoregulation by controlling blood flow in the skin.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Dysplastic melanocytes: Associated with melanoma, which may be pigmented, irregular, and not typically exquisitely tender or cold-sensitive.

 

Option B. Capillary endothelial cells: Found in hemangiomas; these are usually soft, compressible, and not extremely painful or cold-sensitive.

 

Option D. Osteoclasts: Involved in bone resorption, not the origin of subungual painful lesions like glomus tumors.

questions.text: A 42-year-old female complains of soft, fluctuating swelling in front of the knee. She reports discomfort and difficulty while moving her knee. MRI is shown below. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Housemaid's knee

 

Housemaid's knee is the lay term for prepatellar bursitis, which presents as a soft, fluctuant swelling directly anterior to the patella—the clinical and imaging features described in this scenario. The MRI would show fluid collection in the prepatellar bursa, situated immediately in front of the patella, consistent with prepatellar bursitis. Patients with this condition often have discomfort with knee movement and may have a history of prolonged kneeling.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cleryman’s knee: This is infrapatellar bursitis, which produces swelling below the patella (not directly over it), at the level of the tibial tuberosity.

 

Option C. Gout: out can affect bursae but typically demonstrates tophi or urate crystal deposits, often with erythema, redness, and sometimes skin breakdown; the described features and swelling location are less characteristic.

 

Option D. Pes anserinus bursitis: Presents as swelling and tenderness on the medial side of the knee, well below the patella and not in its anterior aspect

questions.text: A 34-year-old male patient presented with pain and tightness on the glans penis and pigmentation with difficulty in urination. Examination finding is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Balanitis xerotica

 

The image depicts white, atrophic, sclerotic patches affecting the glans penis with ulceration and difficulty in retracting the foreskin, suggestive of balanitis xerotica obliterans (also termed lichen sclerosus), a chronic inflammatory condition causing pain, tightening, and urinary symptoms.

 

Other Options:


Option B. Condyloma acuminata: Presents as exophytic, warty lesions due to HPV infection, usually not ulcerative or sclerotic.


Option C. Erythroplasia of Queyrat (EQ): Appears as a red, velvety plaque on the glans, not as white sclerosed tissue.


Option D. Peyronie’s disease: Characterized by fibrous plaques in the tunica albuginea causing penile curvature, not cutaneous or mucosal lesions.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man presents with severe pain in his gums, foul breath, and bleeding during brushing for the past week. On examination, his gingivae are red, edematous, and covered with ulcers and a necrotic membrane. The patient reports poor oral hygiene and stress due to a recent workload increase. Which of the following organisms is most commonly associated with this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Fusiform bacilli 

 

  • Vincent’s angina, also known as acute necrotizing ulcerative gingivitis (ANUG), is caused by a synergistic infection of Fusiform bacilli and Borrelia vincenti. 
  • It is characterized by painful, ulcerative lesions on the gingivae with necrotic membrane formation. 
  • Risk factors include poor oral hygiene, stress, and immunosuppression.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Streptococcus mutans: This organism is primarily associated with dental caries and not necrotizing ulcerative gingivitis.

 

Option C. Actinomyces israelii: This bacterium is the causative agent of actinomycosis, which typically presents as chronic, suppurative infections, often with draining sinuses.

 

Option D. Treponema pallidum: This organism causes syphilis, characterized by painless chancres and systemic manifestations, but not gingival necrosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Vincent's angina (acute necrotizing ulcerative gingivitis) is caused by Fusiform bacilli and Borrelia vincenti and presents with painful gingival ulcers, necrotic membranes, and foul breath.

questions.text: A 22-year-old woman presented with burns injury. She is covered with burns on her head and neck, both upper limbs, front and back of the chest. Calculate the percentage of burns?
What is the likely diagnosis based on the given image?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Aneurysmal bone cyst

 

The radiograph shows an expansile, eccentric lytic lesion in the metaphysis of the proximal tibia with thin cortical margins. This is characteristic of an aneurysmal bone cyst (ABC), which typically affects children and young adults. ABCs present with rapid onset pain and swelling and often demonstrate a “soap-bubble” appearance on imaging due to multiple blood-filled cavities.

 

Other Options
 

Option A. Giant cell tumour: Usually arises in the epiphysis of long bones in adults and displays a more aggressive, subarticular appearance; not typically seen in children or metaphyseal locations.

 

 

Option B. Osteoblastoma: A rare benign bone tumour, often larger and found in the spine or posterior elements, not metaphyseal long bones. 

 

 

Option D. Osteoid osteoma: Presents as a small radiolucent nidus with surrounding sclerosis, commonly in the cortex of diaphyseal bone, and is associated with night pain relieved by NSAIDs.

A 50-year-old male presents with jaundice, progressive fatigue, and weight loss. Seven months ago, he underwent orthotopic liver transplantation for alcoholic cirrhosis. On examination, scleral icterus is noted. Laboratory studies reveal elevated ALT, AST, and bilirubin levels. Liver biopsy shows perivenular fibrosis, intimal inflammation, and loss of bile ducts. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Chronic transplant rejection

 

  • Chronic transplant rejection in liver transplant patients is characterized by progressive bile duct loss (vanishing bile duct syndrome), perivenular fibrosis, and intimal inflammation. 
  • These histological findings, coupled with the timeline (several months post-transplant), elevated liver enzymes, and bilirubin, strongly point toward chronic rejection.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Graft-versus-host disease: This typically occurs in bone marrow or hematopoietic stem cell transplants rather than liver transplants. It is associated with skin, gut, and liver involvement but not bile duct loss.

 

Option C. Acute transplant rejection: Acute rejection usually occurs within the first 3 months post-transplant. It is characterized by mixed inflammatory infiltrate in the portal tracts and endothelial inflammation but not bile duct loss or fibrosis.

 

Option D. Recurrence of primary disease: Recurrence of alcoholic cirrhosis is unlikely within this short timeframe and does not typically result in the histological findings of bile duct loss or perivenular fibrosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Chronic transplant rejection in liver transplant patients leads to progressive bile duct loss and fibrosis, distinguishing it from other causes of post-transplant liver dysfunction.

Which of these open inguinal hernia repairs involves double breasting of conjoint tendon with inguinal ligament?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Shouldice’s repair

 

  • Shouldice's repair is an open inguinal hernia repair involving the following steps:
    1. The conjoint tendon is sutured to the inguinal ligament in multiple overlapping (double-breasting) layers.
    2. This technique strengthens the posterior wall of the inguinal canal using continuous sutures.
    3. It is considered a pure tissue repair, meaning no prosthetic mesh is used.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bassini’s repair:

 

  • In Bassini’s repair, the conjoint tendon is approximated to the inguinal ligament in a single layer.
  • This technique does not involve double-breasting and is simpler compared to Shouldice repair.

 

Option B. Maloney’s repair

 

  • Maloney’s repair is a variation of hernia repair, but it does not involve the double-breasting of tissue layers.
  • It is not as commonly practiced as other techniques.

 

Option D. Desarda’s repair:

 

  • Desarda’s repair uses a strip of external oblique aponeurosis, which is sutured to the conjoint tendon and inguinal ligament to reinforce the posterior wall of the inguinal canal.
  • It functions dynamically by tightening during abdominal muscle contraction, but it does not involve double-breasting of the conjoint tendon.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Shouldice repair is a tissue-based open inguinal hernia repair involving double-breasting of the conjoint tendon with the inguinal ligament. 
  • This technique is recognized for its superior outcomes and low recurrence rates compared to other tissue repairs.

choices.text: It is the most common benign neoplasm of the salivary glands

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman presented to the surgery OPD with complaints of a slow-growing painless swelling on the right side of her mouth for the past 2 years. The swelling is lobular and non-tender. Investigations of the swelling reveal a pleomorphic adenoma. Which of the following statements is correct regarding the diagnosis of this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) It is most common benign neoplasm of the salivary glands 

 

  • Pleomorphic adenoma is the most common benign salivary gland tumor, accounting for a significant percentage of all such neoplasms.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. It never undergoes malignant transformation: This statement is incorrect. Pleomorphic adenoma can undergo malignant transformation, although this is considered rare. The risk of transformation increases with the duration the tumor is present.

 

Option C. Core biopsy is needed for diagnosis: This statement is incorrect. While a core biopsy can provide a diagnosis, fine needle aspiration (FNA) is often the first-line approach for the evaluation of salivary gland masses due to its simplicity and lower risk of complications. Core biopsy may lead to seeding the biopsy tract with tumor cells and is avoided.

 

Option D. It can be treated by enucleation: This statement is incorrect. Enucleation, or simple removal of the tumor without removing surrounding normal tissue, is not recommended for pleomorphic adenoma due to the risk of recurrence and potential for tumor spillage. The tumor shows extensions (pseudopodia) which may be left behind if enucleation is done.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • Pleomorphic adenoma is the most common benign neoplasm of the salivary glands and should be treated with complete surgical excision (superficial parotidectomy) rather than enucleation to minimize the risk of recurrence.

A patient presents with groin swelling which worsens on coughing. The swelling appears to arise above the inguinal crease, but reaches the bottom of scrotum. On occlusion of deep ring, the swelling doesn’t appear. What is the pathology?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Indirect inguinal hernia

 

  • An indirect inguinal hernia arises when abdominal contents pass through the deep inguinal ring, traveling along the inguinal canal, and may reach the scrotum.
  • In this case, the swelling appears above the inguinal crease and extends into the scrotum. 
  • The deep ring occlusion test is a confirmatory test for indirect inguinal hernia. 
  • When the deep ring is occluded, the swelling does not appear, indicating that the herniated contents are passing through the deep inguinal ring.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Femoral hernia: A femoral hernia arises below the inguinal crease and protrudes through the femoral canal. It is more common in women and does not reach the scrotum.

 

Option B. Direct inguinal hernia: A direct inguinal hernia protrudes directly through the posterior wall of the inguinal canal and is medial to the inferior epigastric vessels. It does not pass through the deep ring and usually does not extend into the scrotum.

 

Option D. Paraumbilical hernia: A paraumbilical hernia occurs near the umbilicus and is unrelated to the inguinal region. It presents as a swelling near the umbilical area, not the groin.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • An indirect inguinal hernia arises from the deep inguinal ring and is the most common type of hernia in both men and women. 
  • It can be distinguished from a direct inguinal hernia by its location and the deep ring occlusion test.

questions.text: Which of the following is not included in the Rockall scoring system for predicting mortality and rebleeding risk in patients with upper gastrointestinal bleeding?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Hemoglobin

 

  • The Rockall scoring system evaluates the risk of mortality and rebleeding in upper gastrointestinal bleeding using the following factors:
    1. Age
    2. Presence of shock (systolic blood pressure and pulse)
    3. Comorbidities (such as renal failure, liver failure, or coronary artery disease)
    4. Endoscopic diagnosis
    5. Major stigmata of recent hemorrhage (Forrest grade)
  • Hemoglobin levels are not included in the Rockall scoring system. 

  • However, the Glasgow-Blatchford score, another commonly used scoring system, does incorporate hemoglobin and blood urea nitrogen (BUN) levels to predict the need for intervention in patients with upper GI bleeding.

     

Other Options:

 

Option A. Forrest grade: The Forrest classification assesses stigmata of recent hemorrhage seen on endoscopy and is a key component of the Rockall score. It includes classifications such as active spurting bleeding (Forrest I) or visible vessel (Forrest II).

 

Option B. Presence of coronary artery disease: Comorbid conditions like coronary artery disease, renal failure, and liver failure are included in the Rockall scoring system and significantly impact the overall score.

 

Option C. Systolic BP: Systolic blood pressure and pulse are used to assess the degree of shock in the patient, making them an integral part of the Rockall score.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The Rockall scoring system evaluates the risk of mortality and rebleeding in patients with upper gastrointestinal bleeding based on age, comorbidities, systolic BP and pulse (shock), endoscopic findings, and Forrest grade. 
  • Hemoglobin levels are not included in the Rockall score but are part of the Glasgow-Blatchford score.

questions.text: A 19-year-old male presents with localized bone pain in the tibia. Imaging reveals a small radiolucent lesion surrounded by dense reactive sclerosis. The pain improves with NSAIDs. Which of the following is a histological feature of the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Trabeculae of woven bone surrounded by fibrovascular stroma

 

  • Osteoid osteoma exhibits a characteristic histological pattern of trabeculae of woven bone surrounded by fibrovascular stroma within a nidus. 
  • This benign lesion is often associated with inflammatory changes in the surrounding cortical bone, leading to reactive sclerosis and pain due to prostaglandin production.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Malignant osteoid production with atypical mitoses: This is a feature of osteosarcoma, a high-grade malignant bone tumor. Osteosarcomas show aggressive growth, cortical destruction, and periosteal reactions, which are not seen in osteoid osteoma.

 

Option C. Multinucleated giant cells surrounding hemorrhagic spaces: Seen in aneurysmal bone cysts, which are expansile lesions with fluid-filled spaces and lack the histological features of woven bone and fibrovascular stroma.

 

Option D. Fibrous tissue with scattered irregular bony trabeculae: This describes fibrous dysplasia, a non-neoplastic condition involving abnormal fibro-osseous tissue.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Osteoid osteomas are histologically characterized by trabeculae of woven bone surrounded by fibrovascular stroma, and they are associated with reactive cortical changes.

questions.text: The criteria for early renal graft dysfunction includes:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Rise in serum creatinine of >10% baseline

 

  • Early graft dysfunction is defined by a rise in serum creatinine >10% from baseline in the immediate post-transplant period.
  • It reflects impaired graft function and may require further evaluation for rejection, obstruction, or vascular compromise.
  • Absolute creatinine changes (μmol/L) are less reliable than percentage change from baseline in this context.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Rise in serum creatinine of >15% baseline: Incorrect. too high a threshold, may delay diagnosis of early dysfunction.

 

Option C. Rise in serum creatinine of >10 μmol/L: Incorrect. absolute value insufficient, does not account for baseline.

 

Option D. Rise in serum creatinine of >15 μmol/L: Incorrect. same as above, percentage change is standard.

A person presents with a tongue ulcer persisting for 3 months. Upon examination, a lesion measuring 3.5 cm x 2.5 cm is observed, accompanied by an 8 mm area of hardened tissue. No lymph node enlargement is detected. According to the 8th AJCC guidelines, what stage does this lesion correspond to?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) T2

 

(AJCC 8th Edition – Oral Tongue Cancer)

 

Tumor staging is based on greatest dimension + depth of invasion (DOI):

 

  • T1: Tumor ≤2 cm in greatest dimension and DOI ≤5 mm
  • T2: Tumor ≤2 cm with DOI >5 mm and ≤10 mm
      OR Tumor >2 cm but ≤4 cm with DOI ≤10 mm
  • T3: Tumor >4 cm OR DOI >10 mm
  • T4a: Moderately advanced local disease → invasion into adjacent structures (cortex of mandible, maxilla, skin of face, deep muscles of tongue, etc.)

 

Applying to This Case:

 

  • Tumor size = 3.5 × 2.5 cm → largest dimension = 3.5 cm.
  • Area of induration = 8 mm → this corresponds to depth of invasion (DOI = 8 mm).
  • No nodal involvement → N0.

 

Now match with AJCC criteria:

 

  • Tumor is >2 cm but ≤4 cm = qualifies for T2.
  • DOI = 8 mm (≤10 mm) = still fits T2, not T3.

 

So, staging = T2 N0 M0 → Stage II.

questions.text: A young marathon runner is participating in a marathon competition. After running for 100 m, he develops pain at the anteromedial aspect of tibia which was mild to start with, but increased on further running. X-ray was normal. The doctor ordered a bone scan. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Shin splint

 

STRESS/FATIGUE FRACTURE

 

  • Stress fracture is due to imbalance between load and resistance of bone.
  • It is of 2 types:
  1. Fatigue fracture: Caused by application of abnormal stress on normal bone.
  2. Insufficiency fracture: Caused by normal activity on weak bone.
  • Sites of Stress Fractures:
  1. Lower Extremity:
    • March fracture is a stress fatigue fracture of second metatarsal neck > 3rd metatarsal neck. The most common site is metatarsal neck followed by tibia (proximal third in children, middle third in athlete and lower third in elderly).
    • Tibia stress fracture = Shin splints
    • Femoral neck (inferomedial compression side in young and superior tension side in older patients).
    • Rarely fibula lower end (runner’s fracture).
  2. Upper Extremity:
    • Olecranon is most common site of upper limb stress fractures.
  3. Pelvis and Spine:
    • Pars interarticularis of 5th lumbar vertebral (causing spondylolysis) is commonest in spine.

 

  • Clinical Presentation:
    • Load related pain often bilateral
    • The hallmark physical finding is tenderness with palpation and stress.
  • Investigation:
    • MRI provides excellent sensitivity and superior specificity compared to bone scan in differentiating from infections or tumors.
    • Bone scan is preferable for bilateral cases due to feasibility, also bilateral cases go in favour of stress fracture as compared to Infection or tumor and also can scan the whole body.
  • Treatment: Symptomatic with cast and cessation of activity.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Lisfranc fracture: A Lisfranc dislocation is a spectrum of injuries involving the tarsometatarsal joints of the foot. The Lisfranc joint is composed of the articulation between the first, second, and third metatarsals bones, and the cuneiform bones. Injury of the joint can range from complete tarsometatarsal displacement with associated fractures and ligamentous tears to partial sprains with no displacement. Lisfranc injuries are uncommon and are often misdiagnosed. Even when recognized and treated promptly, there is still a high risk for chronic disability and complications. There are two main mechanisms of injury: direct, and indirect. A direct mechanism occurs as a crush injury to the joint from motor vehicle collision or industrial accident. An indirect injury is more common and is often associated with sports participation involving a longitudinal force with the foot in plantarflexion with a medial or lateral rotational force. The patient presents with complaint of midfoot pain with weight-bearing, following an acute injury. The pain worsens by forefoot weight bearing, and the patient may describe pain or difficulty with the push-off phases of walking and/or running. There is pain with abduction and eversion of the forefoot. Pain can also commonly be reproduced with passive pronation or supination of the tarsometatarsal joint. Radiographic findings show misalignment of the lateral margin of the first metatarsal base with the lateral edge of the medial cuneiform, misalignment of the medial aspect of the second metatarsal base with the medial edge of the middle cuneiform, and/or small avulsion fragments a one of metatarsal or cuneiform bones. On oblique view, the medial aspect of the cuboid should line up with the medial aspect of the fourth metatarsal base. The dorsal cortex of the first metatarsal and medial cuneiform should be aligned on the lateral radiographs. Lisfranc injuries can be managed operatively. Initial treatment includes reduction, splinting, and elevation. After six weeks, if the patient is non-tender and radiographs are negative, then begin weight-bearing and rehabilitation. If there is any tenderness but no displacement, then the patient should be in a boot or cast for at least another four weeks before starting rehabilitation. Any displacement requires surgical fixation.

 

 

Option B. Jones fracture: A Jones fracture is a fracture of the proximal metadiaphyseal junction of the fifth metatarsal bone that involves the 4th-5th metatarsal articulation. The fracture occurs as a result of significant adduction force to the forefoot with the ankle in plantar flexion. On a plain radiograph, Jones fracture is located at the metadiaphyseal junction, approximately 2 cm (1.5-3 cm) from the tip of the 5th metatarsal and has a predominantly horizontal course. It should not extend distally. Jones fractures are particularly prone to non-union due to being in a vascular watershed zone and take longer than two months to heal. Displacement of the fracture can increase with persistent weight-bearing; therefore, immobilization is important, with a non-weight bearing cast for 6-8 weeks. Indications for non-operative management include undisplaced fractures and fractures in patients with limited activity (i.e. recreational athletes). Operative management is indicated in patients that are elite or competitive athletes or when delayed union has occurred. Management includes either intramedullary screw fixation or open reduction and internal fixation. 

 

 

Option D. Nutcracker fracture: A nutcracker fracture refers to a cuboid bone fracture with associated navicular avulsion fracture due to compression between the bases of 4th and 5th metatarsals and calcaneus bone. The injury usually occurs secondary to the traumatic abduction of the forefoot. This results in loss of the normal lateral column support and excess valgus force upon the medial column that commonly causes rupture of tibialis posterior tendon or avulsion fracture of its attachment onto medial aspect of the tarsal navicular bone. Nutcracker fractures are clinically significant because they can interfere with the medchanical alignment of the foot.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Shint splint or stress fracture of tibia is the most common injury in runners.

questions.solution: Ans. A) Areas of bony erosions and new bone formation

questions.text: A 60-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by ambulance for right-sided weakness and slurred speech that started 30 minutes ago. The wife reports that her husband said he was dizzy, and shortly after, he developed acute right arm and leg weakness and was unable to speak. Medical history includes hypertension, for which he takes amlodipine. The patient also takes an aspirin daily. Blood pressure is 225/110 mm Hg, pulse is 90/min, and respirations are 20/min. On examination, the patient is alert but aphasic with 0/5 strength in the right upper and lower extremities. Examination of the left upper and lower extremities is normal. A nicardipine infusion is started and CT scan of the head is performed. After returning from the CT scanner, the patient is minimally responsive and has developed hyperextension of all four extremities. CT scan shows a left-sided intracerebral hemorrhage with a 5-mm midline shift to the right. Which of the following is the best next step in management of this patient?
questions.solution: Ans. D) Intubate and mechanically ventilate

questions.text: A 32-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 6-week history of left shoulder pain, numbness, and tingling in his left hand. He mentions that the symptoms worsen when he raises his arm above his head. He works as a construction worker, frequently lifting heavy tools. Physical examination reveals decreased fine touch in the 4th and 5th fingers of the left hand and weakened grip strength on the left side. Palpation of the neck reveals diffuse pain. The patient’s left arm is held in abduction, extension, and external rotation, and he is instructed to turn his head toward it while breathing deeply, causing a decreased radial pulse on the left side. Which of the following is the most likely cause of the patient’s findings?
questions.solution: Ans. D) Anterior scalene muscle hypertrophy

A 34-year-old female presents with a lump in her left breast for 2 years. On examination, a 6 x 4 cm mass is palpated. Dimpling of the skin and bloody discharge from the nipple is present. The lesion is invading the pectoralis major muscle. Ipsilateral Level I and Level II matted axillary lymph nodes and contralateral Level 1 axillary nodes are present. There was no distant metastasis. What is the TNM staging?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) T3N2M1

 

  • T3: Tumor >5 cm but ≤10 cm (6×4 cm).
  • N2: Ipsilateral axillary nodes clinically fixed or matted; contralateral node involvement increases N category.
  • M1: Presence of contralateral axillary node involvement is considered distant metastasis.
  • TNM staging guides treatment planning, prognosis, and adjuvant therapy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. T4bN1M0: Incorrect. T4b requires ulceration or skin involvement, not just dimpling.

 

Option B. T3N2M0: Incorrect. contralateral nodal involvement → M1, not M0.

 

Option C. T4aN1M0: Incorrect. T4a = chest wall invasion; only skin dimpling present here.

A patient presented with pleuritic chest pain and absent breath sounds on the right side. A dull note is felt on percussion. What is the best chest x-ray view to diagnose this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Right Lateral decubitus view

 

Option D:

 

Lateral decubitus view is the best view to identify pleural effusion. It can identify as little as 25 ml of pleural fluid.

 

Right Lateral decubitus view - For suspected right-sided pleural effusion, the right lateral decubitus view is best. The patient lies on the right side, and if pleural fluid is present, it will shift and layer in the pleural space, creating a meniscus that is visible on the x-ray.

 

Explanation:

 

 

Option A. PA view: The posteroanterior (PA) view is a standard chest x-ray view that provides an overview of the lungs, heart, and great vessels. It's useful for many thoracic conditions but may not always be the best option to detect small pleural effusions.

 

Option B. Right anterior oblique (RAO): This view allows for better visualization of the lung fields and is commonly used to visualize the heart, great vessels, and posterior ribs. However, it's not typically used for identifying pleural effusions.

 

Option C. Left Lateral decubitus view: This position is useful when looking for pleural effusions on the left side. In this view, the patient lies on their left side, and free pleural fluid shifts, allowing better visualization.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The right lateral decubitus view is the most sensitive chest x-ray position to identify pleural effusion on the right side. It can detect as little as 25 ml of pleural fluid, demonstrating the meniscus sign and blunting of the costophrenic angle. For comprehensive assessment, ultrasonography remains the most sensitive imaging modality, capable of detecting even smaller volumes of pleural fluid.

 

Features of chest radiograph in pleural effusion:

 

SIGN: meniscus sign/ Ellis S curve

 

EARLIEST FINDING: blunting of CP angle

 

MEDIASTINAL SHIFT: C/L shift

 

MOST SENSITIVE IX: USG (can pick up 10 -20 ml)

 

MOST SENSITIVE X RAY – I/L lateral decubitus

 

 

Figure 1 Image showing Pleural effusion – Source: - Wikipedia

 

Ref: Grainger & Allison’s Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, Second Edition

questions.text: The caecum is found to be placed below the stomach and is midline. Which of the following abnormalities must have taken place while rotation of the gut?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Mixed Rotation 

 

During embryological development, the midgut rotates 270° counterclockwise around the superior mesenteric artery (SMA).

 

  • Normal rotation: places the caecum in the right lower quadrant.
  • Mixed rotation: part of the midgut rotates normally, while another part malrotates. This can result in abnormal positioning such as the caecum lying below the stomach, in the midline.
    • It is a combination of malrotation and nonrotation features.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Malrotation:

 

  • Incomplete rotation of midgut.
  • Caecum may lie in subhepatic region (right upper quadrant), not below stomach in midline.

 

Option B. Nonrotation:

 

  • Midgut fails to rotate the final 180°.
  • Caecum ends up on the left side of abdomen, not midline.

 

Option C. Reverse rotation:

 

  • Midgut rotates in the clockwise direction instead of counterclockwise.
  • Leads to duodenum lying anterior to SMA and transverse colon posterior to SMA.
  • Not associated with caecum lying below the stomach.
